Simple functions play a crucial role in the construction of the Lebesgue integral, as they serve as the building blocks for more general measurable functions. Any non-negative measurable function can be approximated by an increasing sequence of simple functions.

The Lebesgue integral is a generalization of the Riemann integral that allows for the integration of a broader class of functions. It is defined for measurable functions on a measure space (X, \mathcal {A}, \mu ).
The construction of the Lebesgue integral proceeds in several steps:

fr:ol.fr:li: First, define the integral for non-negative simple functions (finite linear combinations of indicator functions of measurable sets).
Then, extend this definition to non-negative measurable functions using monotone approximation by simple functions.
Finally, define the integral for general measurable functions by separately integrating their positive and negative parts.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The Lebesgue integral has many advantages over the Riemann integral:

fr:ul.fr:li: It allows for the integration of a larger class of functions
It has better convergence properties, exemplified by the Monotone Convergence Theorem and Lebesgue's Dominated Convergence Theorem
It provides a more natural setting for limiting operations and for the study of function spaces like L^p spaces

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X, \mathcal {A}) and (Y, \mathcal {B}) be measurable spaces, where \mathcal {A} and \mathcal {B} are Ïƒ-algebras on X and Y, respectively. A function f: X \to Y is said to be measurable if the preimage of every measurable set in Y is a measurable set in X.
Formally, f is \mathcal {A}-\mathcal {B} measurable if f^{-1}(B) \in \mathcal {A} for all B \in \mathcal {B}.

In the context of real-valued functions on \mathbb {R}^d, a function f: \mathbb {R}^d \to \mathbb {R} is Lebesgue measurable if the preimage of every Borel set in \mathbb {R} is a Lebesgue measurable set in \mathbb {R}^d.
Equivalently, a function f: \mathbb {R}^d \to \mathbb {R} is Lebesgue measurable if and only if the set \{x \in \mathbb {R}^d : f(x) > a\} is Lebesgue measurable for every a \in \mathbb {R}.
